content.intro: A professional-grade 10G homelab that rivals $8,000+ commercial solutions for just $2,459.
Get everything ready before starting the hardware installation.
Install RAM, NVMe SSD, and hard drives into the TerraMaster unit.

items.title: Install 64GB DDR5 RAM
items.content: Remove bottom panel, locate RAM slot, remove existing 8GB module, install new 64GB DDR5-5600 SODIMM.

items.title: Install 1TB NVMe SSD
items.content: Insert WD_BLACK SN7100 into M.2 Slot 1 at 30° angle, press flat, secure with screw.

items.title: Install Hard Drives
items.content: Insert 4× WD Red Plus 12TB into drive bays 1-4 using tool-less trays.

content.intro: Install TrueNAS SCALE operating system and configure basic settings.

sections.title: ⚠️ CRITICAL: User Creation Timing
sections.content: You MUST create the admin user (UID 1000) BEFORE creating any ZFS pools in Phase 3. This ensures correct file permissions. Verify user creation with: id huynguyen

items.title: Boot from USB Installer
items.content: Insert USB, press DEL or F11 during boot, select USB device.

items.title: Install TrueNAS to NVMe
items.content: Choose Install/Upgrade, select /dev/nvme0n1, set root password, wait ~5 minutes.

items.title: Configure Static IP
items.content: Set static IP 10.20.30.100 in Network → Global Configuration.

items.title: Create Admin User
items.content: Create user 'huynguyen' with UID 1000 for proper file permissions.

content.intro: Verify basic network connectivity and update TrueNAS before proceeding to storage configuration.

sections.title: Network Verification
items: Verify web GUI access from PC

items.title: Update TrueNAS
items.content: Navigate to System → Update, check for updates, download and install if available. System will reboot (~5 minutes).

items.title: Verify Services
items.content: After reboot, confirm all services started: System → Services. SSH should be enabled for future troubleshooting.

content.intro: Create ZFS pools and datasets for optimal performance and organization.

sections.title: ⚠️ CRITICAL: NVMe Boot Pool Protection
sections.content: Before creating apps-ssd pool, verify boot pool location: zpool status boot-pool and lsblk /dev/nvme0n1. Ensure you ONLY use free space (typically nvme0n1p3). DO NOT accidentally erase boot-pool!

sections.title: Storage Strategy
sections.content:
Two-Pool Design:
• tank (HDD RAIDZ1): Bulk storage for media (36TB usable)
• apps-ssd (NVMe): Fast storage for app configs (~900GB usable)

sections.title: 🚨 POINT OF NO RETURN
sections.content:
WARNING: Creating ZFS pools ERASES ALL DATA on those drives!

Before running 'zpool create tank raidz1 /dev/sd[abcd]':
✓ Triple-check device names: lsblk
✓ Verify no mounted filesystems: mount | grep sd
✓ Confirm backup exists elsewhere
✓ Take photos of disk serial numbers

This operation is IRREVERSIBLE!

items.title: Create Pool 'tank'
items.content: 4× 12TB RAIDZ1 configuration with lz4 compression.

items.title: Create Pool 'apps-ssd'
items.content: Single NVMe drive for application data and databases.

items.title: Create Datasets
items.content: Organize data into media, photos, documents, downloads, backups, and app datasets.

content.intro: Set up 10G networking with LACP bonding for 20 Gbps aggregate bandwidth.

items.title: Baseline 10G Test (BEFORE LACP)
items.content: Connect SINGLE cable TerraMaster Port 1 → USW Port 2. Verify 10G link speed. Run iperf3 single stream test (~9.4 Gbps expected). This confirms cabling/NICs work before LACP complexity.

items.title: Install USW-Aggregation
items.content: Rack mount switch, connect to UDM, adopt in UniFi controller.

items.title: Create Link Aggregation Groups
items.content: LAG1 for TerraMaster (Ports 2-3), LAG2 for Proxmox (Ports 4-5).

items.title: Configure TrueNAS LACP Bond
items.content: Create bond0 with 2×10G interfaces, set MTU 9000.

items.title: Configure Proxmox LACP Bond
items.content: Install QLogic NIC, configure bond0 with LACP.

items.title: Performance Test
items.content: Run iperf3 test, verify 18-20 Gbps aggregate bandwidth.

content.intro: Configure VLANs and firewall rules for network segmentation and security.

sections.title: ⚠️ Backup Plan for VLAN Changes
sections.content:
VLAN changes can cause loss of connectivity!

Before starting:
✓ Have console/keyboard access ready
✓ Document rollback command: ip addr add 10.20.30.100/24 dev enp1s0
✓ Test VLAN access BEFORE removing native VLAN 1
✓ Consider: Keep TrueNAS on Admin VLAN 1 (untagged) for simplicity

sections.title: Firewall Rules
sections.content: Configure rules to allow Home → NAS services, block Home → Infrastructure, allow IoT backups, complete guest isolation.

content.intro: Migrate all data from QNAP to TrueNAS using parallel rsync for maximum speed.

sections.title: Pre-Migration Validation (CRITICAL)
items: Run QNAP SMART tests on all 6 drives
Check QNAP filesystem errors: dmesg | grep -i error
Document file counts: find /share -type f | wc -l

sections.title: Migration Strategy
sections.content: Run 4 parallel rsync jobs (movies, TV, photos, documents) to maximize bandwidth utilization. Expected: ~150 MB/s per stream, ~10 hours total.

items.title: Enable SSH on QNAP
items.content: Enable SSH access for rsync transfers.

items.title: Monitor QNAP CPU Load
items.content: Start with 2 parallel streams (movies + TV). Monitor QNAP CPU with 'top'. If CPU < 80%, add 3rd stream. If CPU < 85%, add 4th. QNAP Atom CPU may throttle at 90-95%.

items.title: Set Up Screen Sessions
items.content: Create 4 screen sessions for parallel transfers.

items.title: Start Parallel Transfers
items.content: Launch rsync jobs for movies, TV shows, photos, and documents simultaneously.

items.title: Monitor Progress
items.content: Check transfer speeds and completion status.

items.title: Verify Data
items.content: Compare file counts and sizes, spot-check random files.

content.intro: Verify data integrity and completeness after migration from QNAP.

sections.title: Data Integrity Verification
items: Verify checksums for critical data (photos, documents)
Spot-check 20+ random files across all datasets
Test file access: Play random movie, open photos
Verify no permission errors in TrueNAS logs
Compare total disk usage: du -sh on both systems

items.title: Test Media Playback
items.content: Open 5+ random video files. Verify they play without corruption. Check audio sync and video quality.

items.title: Test Document Access
items.content: Open 10+ random documents (PDFs, Office files). Verify no corruption or missing content.

items.title: Test Photo Library
items.content: Browse photo directories. Open random images. Verify thumbnails generate correctly.

sections.title: ⚠️ DO NOT Proceed Until
sections.content:
✓ All file counts match
✓ No rsync errors in logs
✓ Random file spot-checks pass
✓ TrueNAS shows no errors

Keep QNAP powered on and data intact for at least 7 days as insurance!

content.intro: Validate system performance and ensure all components meet specifications.

sections.title: Success Criteria
items: ZFS Read: ~1,200 MB/s (cache miss), ~12,000 MB/s (ARC cache hit)
LACP Bonds: Both showing Aggregator ID 1, 2×10G active

sections.title: Extended Burn-In Testing (Recommended)
sections.content:
Optional but highly recommended for production use:

✓ Run iperf3 for 1 hour continuous (stability test)
✓ Run fio disk stress test: 24 hours
✓ Monitor drive temps during heavy I/O (should stay < 50°C)
✓ Verify ZFS scrub completes without errors
✓ Check kernel errors: dmesg | grep -i error

This catches infant mortality failures before you rely on the system.

content.intro: Configure automated tasks and monitoring for long-term reliability.

sections.title: Automated Tasks
sections.content:
SMART Tests: Weekly long tests (Sunday 2 AM)
ZFS Scrubs: Monthly integrity checks
Snapshots: Photos hourly (30-day), Media daily (7-day), Documents 6-hourly (60-day)
Email Alerts: Pool status, SMART failures, high temps

sections.title: Critical: TrueNAS Config Backup
items: System → General → Save Config → Download .tar file
Store config on: External drive + cloud + Proxmox
Export pool info: zpool export tank (for disaster recovery docs)
Document: Pool creation commands, dataset structure
Test: Restore config on test VM to verify backup works

content.intro: Safely decommission the QNAP after confirming TrueNAS is stable and all data is verified.

sections.title: ⚠️ Wait Period Required
sections.content:
DO NOT decommission QNAP until:
✓ TrueNAS has been stable for 7+ days
✓ You've accessed files daily without issues
✓ All services (Plex, etc.) work correctly
✓ You're 100% confident data is intact

The QNAP is your insurance policy - don't rush this!

sections.title: Final Backup (Paranoia Backup)
items: One final checksum verification of critical files
Document any files you intentionally didn't migrate
Take screenshots of QNAP setup for documentation
Verify you have TrueNAS config backups elsewhere

items.title: Update Client Mount Points
items.content: Update all devices pointing to QNAP NFS/SMB shares to use TrueNAS (10.20.30.100) instead. Test each client.

items.title: Update Documentation
items.content: Update network diagrams, wiki pages, configuration management with new TrueNAS paths and IPs.

items.title: Power Down QNAP
items.content: Gracefully shut down QNAP from web interface. Wait 7 more days with it powered off but data intact.

items.title: Wipe QNAP Drives
items.content: After 14 days total, securely wipe QNAP drives if selling/repurposing: dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/sdX bs=1M

items.title: Sell or Repurpose QNAP
items.content: List on eBay/Craigslist. Expected value: $200-$300. Alternatively, repurpose as backup NAS or test system.

sections.title: ✅ Upgrade Complete!
sections.content:
Congratulations! You've successfully upgraded to a professional 10G homelab!

✓ 36TB ZFS RAIDZ1 with enterprise-grade protection
✓ 64GB RAM with 30-40GB ZFS ARC cache
✓ 20 Gbps LACP aggregate bandwidth
✓ Professional network segmentation
✓ Automated monitoring and backups

Total investment: $2,459 CAD (after selling QNAP)
Equivalent commercial solution: $8,000+

🎉 Enjoy your new infrastructure!
